headline: ‘Trump wanted to break us’, says Carney as Liberals triumph in Canadian election | Canada | The Guardian
context: Mark Carney has used his victory speech to claim Donald Trump wanted to “break us” as he led Canada’s Liberal party to a fourth term in office, in a race that was upended by threats and aggression from the US president.

The Liberal triumph capped a miraculous political resurrection and marked a landmark victory for Carney, the former central banker and political novice who only recently succeeded Justin Trudeau as prime minister. Results on Tuesday confirmed that the Liberals fell just short of a majority government and would therefore need the support of political rivals to govern.

annotations.paragraph: Mirroring a theme of the campaign, Carney told election-night supporters that Trump wanted to “break us, so that America can own us”, adding: “That will never, ever happen,” to shouts from the crowd.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct quote from Carney's victory speech, reinforcing the headline's claim about Trump's intentions.

annotations.paragraph: He also gave a stark assessment of a world order once defined by an integrated global trading system with the US at the centre, saying such a system was over, and he pledged to reshape Canada’s relationships with other nations.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers Carney's perspective on global trade and Canada's future relationships, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: “We are over the shock over American betrayal. But we will never forget the lessons,” he said.
annotations.reason: This quote from Carney emphasizes the impact of US actions on Canada, aligning with the article's focus on US-Canada relations.
